justification: The review explains that in the die-under-cup task, "participants were asked to privately roll a die under a paper cup to determine their pay... If participants are honest, they should report the number they observed," making the task a behavioural measure of dishonest reporting.
The article notes that "The use of the sender-receiver game introduced by Gneezy (2005) ... has proven useful for studying some aspects of relational lying, particularly sophisticated deception."
It states that collaborative dishonesty "involves two or more individuals jointly engaging in dishonest acts, such as in the dyadic die-rolling paradigm (Weisel & Shalvi, 2015; Leib et al., 2021)."

The review describes the TLCG as "an experimental task in which participants spontaneously decide to lie (egoistically or altruistically) ... The TLCG proved to be a suitable tool for studying social deception under well-controlled and still rather ecological conditions."
construct: Individual moral dishonesty in gain/loss contexts

justification: Under individual differences it states, "Research has firmly established ... the honesty-humility dimension from the HEXACO model of personality structure ... predicts lying in anonymous, individual settings."

The paper notes that "the common core of so-called 'dark' traits ... the 'dark factor of personality' (D; Moshagen et al., 2018) ... predicts how consistently individuals tell the truth or lie," indicating D is the measurement instrument for that construct.
When discussing moral-dilemma work, it reports that deontological adherence "negatively predicted cheating in a coin-toss paradigm," using the coin-toss task as the behavioural measure of cheating.

In the references to measurement needs, the authors suggest starting "with established measures, such as self-report measures of psychopathy or honesty," citing the Self-Reported Lying Scale (e.g., Elaad et al., 2024) as a tool that quantifies individuals’ lying tendencies.
